image.altText: Israeli soldiers walk on grassy terrain.

items.synopsis: Israel says its infantry and tanks have carried out raids inside the Gaza Strip, its first announcement of a shift from an air war to ground operations to root out Hamas fighters a week after their deadly rampage in southern Israel.

title.children: Israeli military says troops have made their first ground raids into Gaza

image.altText: A woman walks past "vote yes" and "vote no" signs on a fence.

items.synopsis: The nation is bound for the ballot box today to cast their vote in a referendum that could shape the country for generations to come — but the path to this poll has been a rocky one.

title.children: A moment decades in the making: It's time for Australians to cast their votes on a new Voice

image.altText: A person in a crowd holds up a sign with the Aboriginal flag and the words "Voice to Parliament".

items.synopsis: A No vote — and how we got to one — will change the way we see ourselves, and send the most unloving of messages to Indigenous Australians, writes Laura Tingle.

title.children: A prediction made 12 months ago is coming true — and it's sending a painful message

image.altText: Two young men are silhouetted on a city street as they walk beside flames burning on the ground after a protest.

items.synopsis: Israeli ground forces have made raids into Gaza over the past 24 hours, the military says, ahead of an expected ground offensive on the densely populated Palestinian territory.

title.children: Middle East on a knife's edge as Israeli ground invasion of Gaza looms

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The IDF says Israeli ground forces have conducted raids in the Gaza Strip over the past 24 hours, ahead of its expected ground offensive. A statement from the army said it had conducted the "localised" raids to "complete the effort to cleanse the area of terrorists and weaponry", as well as to attempt to find missing people. Hamas militants abducted an estimated 150 Israelis and foreigners during their terror attack in southern Israel last weekend. Read the full story below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israeli troops conduct early ground raids into Gaza

featuredLink.title: Israeli military says troops have made their first ground raids into Gaza

props.alt: Two soldiers jog on a street as a large armoured vehicle kicks up dust in the background.

children.content: An Israeli armoured personnel carrier drives near the Gaza border on Friday.
(Reuters)
The IDF says Israeli ground forces have conducted raids in the Gaza Strip over the past 24 hours, ahead of its expected ground offensive.
A statement from the army said it had conducted the "localised" raids to "complete the effort to cleanse the area of terrorists and weaponry", as well as to attempt to find missing people.
Hamas militants abducted an estimated 150 Israelis and foreigners during their terror attack in southern Israel last weekend.
Read the full story below.

image.altText: Three posters with photographs of people and the words 'bring them home'

items.synopsis: A week after Hamas terrorists' brutal attack on Israel, up to 150 kidnap victims remain in Gaza. Experts on hostage negotiation and terrorism say the world now faces several difficult choices.

title.children: The world's never seen a hostage crisis quite like this. Here's how it could play out

image.altText: A woman sobs as people stand against a sandstone wall at a funeral

items.synopsis: Israel is preparing to carry out a ground operation whose mission is to "destroy Hamas". But what then? What is the political reality and make-up of Gaza and what would it look like without Hamas, asks John Lyons.

title.children: 'Israel now will not stop': One week into war and a dangerous political reality has set in

image.altText: A sullen man looks into the camera.

items.synopsis: There was a time when the name of one whistleblower was on everyone's lips. Kathy Jackson was lauded as a "revolutionary" — but in the shadows was another person waiting to blow the whistle on her.

title.children: The whistleblower who captured the nation — and the man who unmasked her as a fraud

image.altText: A man in a suit, sitting for an interview with a microphone clipped to his tie.

items.synopsis: In 2021, a doctor and pastor met with his friends in Florida allegedly to arrange the overthrow of the Haitian president. Now Kenya is being sent in to help a country plunged into chaos.

title.children: How a group of Florida men allegedly plotted the assassination of the Haitian president and sent the country into chaos

image.altText: composite of fire truck for western australia fire service, people at a beach side pool in sydney and people skiing in perisher

items.synopsis: A quick glance at the national forecast this weekend and you could be forgiven for questioning what season we're in. ABC meteorologist Tom Saunders explains what is driving the country's weather disparity.

title.children: Fire and ice – why is spring weather so changeable?

image.altText: England's Ollie Watkins slides in to score a goal against the Socceroos.

items.synopsis: Graham Arnold helped orchestrate the Socceroos' famous win over England in 2003. Can he do it again as Australia take on their old foes at Wembley? Follow live.

title.children: Socceroos hit woodwork in search of equaliser late against England at Wembley

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: And it's Ollie Watkins who opens the scoring! An initial defensive clearance by Harry Souttar is sent dipping back into the box by Alexander-Arnold, with his cross missed by all Australia's defenders. Instead, it falls right into the chest of Jack Grealish near the back of the six-yard box. He takes a single touch before shooting low and hard across goal, where the Aston Villa striker slides in at the back post to tuck it home. 1-0.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 55' GOAL ENGLAND

children.content: And it's Ollie Watkins who opens the scoring!

An initial defensive clearance by Harry Souttar is sent dipping back into the box by Alexander-Arnold, with his cross missed by all Australia's defenders. Instead, it falls right into the chest of Jack Grealish near the back of the six-yard box.
He takes a single touch before shooting low and hard across goal, where the Aston Villa striker slides in at the back post to tuck it home.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Some eagle-eyed viewers may have spotted current Tottenham manager Ange Postecoglou in the crowd, seated next to the legendary Guus Hiddink. Both former Socceroos managers were guests of Graham Arnold in camp this week, delivering some powerful messages to the squad - and also to Australian football. Postecoglou was asked this week about the impact of the Women's World Cup on the domestic game, and whether the incredible success of that tournament would kick-start football in Australia. Having bemoaned our country's lack of structure, investment, and cultural support for the game in the past, he reiterated those comments this week, saying Australia will probably never become the kind of footballing nation that we believe we can be. “When you look at what the Matildas did at the World Cup: unbelievable,” he said. “But you still won’t see an influx of resources to the game. You won’t, I guarantee it. “I just don’t think the nation as a whole has that inside them to understand you can make an impact on the world of football, but it requires a kind of nationalistic approach that I just don’t think Australians at their core are really interested in." What did you make of Ange's comments? I personally don't think they're very helpful at a time when we're trying to build public support and belief in the sport, but do you think he's right?
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Blasts from the past

children.content: Some eagle-eyed viewers may have spotted current Tottenham manager
Ange Postecoglou
in the crowd, seated next to the legendary
Guus Hiddink
Both former Socceroos managers were guests of
Graham Arnold
in camp this week, delivering some powerful messages to the squad - and also to Australian football.
Postecoglou was asked this week about the impact of the Women's World Cup on the domestic game, and whether the incredible success of that tournament would kick-start football in Australia.

Having bemoaned our country's lack of structure, investment, and cultural support for the game in the past, he reiterated those comments this week, saying Australia will probably never become the kind of footballing nation that we believe we can be.
“When you look at what the Matildas did at the World Cup: unbelievable,” he said.
“But you still won’t see an influx of resources to the game. You won’t, I guarantee it.

“I just don’t think the nation as a whole has that inside them to understand you can make an impact on the world of football, but it requires a kind of nationalistic approach that I just don’t think Australians at their core are really interested in."
What did you make of Ange's comments? I personally don't think they're very helpful at a time when we're trying to build public support and belief in the sport, but do you think he's right?
